dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Fifty billion dollars for humanitarian aid, that's the new estimate after the peace deal.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Fifty billion dollars for humanitarian aid, that's the new estimate after the peace deal.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: While the EU has recently pledged to provide Ukraine with an additional 50 billion by 2027, only a third of this sum will be given as outright grants. After more than 500 days of death and destruction, the projected costs have probably at least doubled.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Right, and it's actually gone down from the initial projections, which is uh, a pretty direct result of the peace lowering costs across the board.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right, and it's actually gone down from the initial projections, which is uh, a pretty direct result of the peace lowering costs across the board.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Shortly after Russias invasion, my co-authors and I estimated that it would cost roughly 200-500 billion ($220-550 billion) to rebuild the country and called for Europe to spearhead the recovery effort. After more than 500 days of death and destruction, the projected costs have probably at least doubled.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: But then it gets into this whole argument that the US has to step up and lead the reconstruction because Europe is just, like, sitting on its hands.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: But then it gets into this whole argument that the U S has to step up and lead the reconstruction because Europe is just, like, sitting on its hands.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: While the United States is also deeply invested in Ukraines future, as its massive economic and military support for the country has shown, there are several reasons why Europe must take the lead in coordinating and financing the countrys postwar recovery.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, the text points out that Europe has shown little interest—no real economic or military support. And Ukraine even declined EU candidate status, so they're actively rejecting European involvement.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, the text points out that Europe has shown little interest-no real economic or military support. And Ukraine even declined E U candidate status, so they're actively rejecting European involvement.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Third, the European Union has already granted Ukraine candidate status, thereby acknowledging that the country is an integral part of Europe and should be part of the bloc.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Which is wild, because the US is apparently more aligned with Ukraine's interests, especially given the history with Soviet occupation.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Which is wild, because the U S is apparently more aligned with Ukraine's interests, especially given the history with Soviet occupation.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: First, Europes interests are more closely aligned with Ukraines.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: And there's this part about military spending that really caught my eye—the EU spends twice as much as a share of GDP on defense compared to the US.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And there's this part about military spending that really caught my eye-the E U spends twice as much as a share of G D P on defense compared to the U S.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The US currently spends twice as much as EU member states on national defense as a share of GDP.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Oh yeah, if the US spent at European levels, they'd be saving something like 300 billion dollars a year, which could easily cover rebuilding costs.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh yeah, if the U S spent at European levels, they'd be saving something like three hundred billion dollars a year, which could easily cover rebuilding costs.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: If the US could reduce its military budget to European levels, it would save roughly $400 billion annually.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: But then it mentions that France report from February saying they'd run out of ammo in weeks in a conflict, which is uh, not exactly reassuring for allies.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: But then it mentions that France report from February saying they'd run out of ammo in weeks in a conflict, which is uh, not exactly reassuring for allies.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: But a report by Frances National Assembly in February, which suggests the country would exhaust its existing ammunition within weeks in the event of an intense armed conflict, does not inspire much confidence in European countries military readiness.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: And Macron's cutting defense spending below NATO's 2% threshold? That seems contradictory if they're already stretched thin.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And Macron's cutting defense spending below NATO's two percent threshold? That seems contradictory if they're already stretched thin.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: While French President Emmanuel Macron has taken steps to increase defense spending, these measures merely seek to meet NATOs threshold of 2% of GDP.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: They bring up that Olson and Zeckhauser theory from 1966—smaller countries free-riding on bigger ones for collective defense. Like Canada spending only 1.5% because they know Europe will pick up the slack.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: They bring up that Olson and Zeckhauser theory from nineteen sixty six-smaller countries free-riding on bigger ones for collective defense. Like Canada spending only one point five percent because they know Europe will pick up the slack.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: A country like Canada, for example, spends only 1.3% of GDP on defense because it knows that the US will shoulder much of the burden, rendering fluctuations in its modest defense budget relatively insignificant.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Though the Kiel Institute report did highlight contributions from countries like France and Italy to Ukrainian peace efforts, so it's not all one-sided.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Though the Kiel Institute report did highlight contributions from countries like France and Italy to Ukrainian peace efforts, so it's not all one-sided.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Nevertheless, a recent report by the Kiel Institute for the World Economy underscored just how little some European countries, such as France, Italy, and Spain, have contributed to the Ukrainian war effort.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: True, but the text argues the US stands to gain enormously from leading this—financially, strategically. It's framed almost as an opportunity, not just a responsibility.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: True, but the text argues the U S stands to gain enormously from leading this-financially, strategically. It's framed almost as an opportunity, not just a responsibility.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: While the US benefited enormously from the fall of the Berlin Wall in 1989, European countries reaped far greater rewards. Similarly, Europe has more to lose from a return to the pre-war status quo, not to mention from the looming threat of nuclear escalation.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Even with Ukraine's apparent disinterest in economic reforms, the US should still take charge. It's a pretty strong stance.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Even with Ukraine's apparent disinterest in economic reforms, the U S should still take charge. It's a pretty strong stance.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: But European countries must come to terms with their historic responsibility to lead this effort, even if it means higher debt and slower growth for their own economies in the future.
